item.title: nb_test
item.description:
Simulation Output Visualisation¶

This notebook takes a look at the raw simulation data (after conversion to GDF) before the velocity decomposition analysis has been completed.

In [1]: 
import sys
import os

import numpy as np
%matplotlib inline
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import matplotlib.animation as anim
from JSAnimation import IPython_display

import yt.mods as ytm
#Import a set of derived fields from pysac
import pysac.io.yt_fields

#Import this repos config
sys.path.append("../..")
from scripts.sacconfig import SACConfig
cfg = SACConfig()

Pick our driver config

In [3]: 
cfg.period = 270.0
cfg.amp = 'A20-3r2'

The first step is to load the data, the yt project makes this very easy:

In [4]: 
timeseries = ytm.load(os.path.join(cfg.gdf_dir,"*_0*.gdf"))
timeseries
Out[4]:
<yt.data_objects.time_series.TimeSeriesData at 0x219aa10>

timeseries is now a light weight wrapper around the sequence of GDF files, it has not read them all into memory!!

It is very easy to create 2D plots using yt:

In [5]: 
ds = timeseries[300]
slc = ytm.SlicePlot(ds, 'x', 'mag_field_magnitude', origin='left-domain', center='center')
slc.set_window_size(8)
slc.set_cmap('mag_field_magnitude', 'algae')
slc.show()

It is also rather easy to create animations:

In [7]: 
slc = ytm.SlicePlot(ds, 'x', 'density_pert', origin='left-domain', center='center')
slc.set_window_size(8)
fig = slc.plots['density_pert'].figure
def animate(i):
    ds = timeseries[i]
    slc._switch_pf(ds)
    slc.set_cmap('density_pert', 'algae')
    slc.set_zlim('density_pert', -6e-10, 6e-10)

anim.FuncAnimation(fig, animate, frames=range(0,len(timeseries),10), interval=50, blit=False)
Out[7]:
<matplotlib.animation.FuncAnimation at 0x5d83b50>
In [8]: 
IIPython_display.display_animation(_)

---------------------------------------------------------------------------
NameError                                 Traceback (most recent call last)
<ipython-input-8-da4d82392561> in <module>()
----> 1 IIPython_display.display_animation(_)

NameError: name 'IIPython_display' is not defined

Volume Rendering:¶

As well as data visualisation and analysis tools, yt also provides a very easy to use parallel volume rendering interface. Below we render the magnitude of the magnetic field pertubation vector.

In []: 
ds = timeseries[400]
In []: 
def get_im(ds, mi, ma, field, field2=None):
    tf = ytm.ColorTransferFunction((mi, ma), grey_opacity=False)
    # Choose a vector representing the viewing direction.
    L = [0.5, 0.5, 0.5]
    c = ds.domain_center
    W = 1.5*ds.domain_width
    Npixels = 512 
    
    # Create a camera object.
    # This object creates the images and
    # can be moved and rotated.
    fields = []
    fields += [field]
    if field2:
        fields += [field2]
    cam = ds.h.camera(c, L, W, Npixels, tf, fields=fields,
                      north_vector=[0,0,-1], steady_north=True, 
                      sub_samples=5, no_ghost=True)
    
    cam.transfer_function.map_to_colormap(mi,ma, 
                                          scale=10.0, colormap='algae')
    #cam.transfer_function.clear()
    #cam.transfer_function.add_layers(50, alpha=np.linspace(mi,ma-1e-7,50), colormap='algae')
    #im = cam.snapshot('test_rendering.png')
    #im = cam.snapshot("%s_volume_rendered.png" % pf)
    #im[im!=im]=0.0
    return cam
In []: 
mi, ma = ds.h.all_data().quantities["Extrema"]('mag_field_pert_magnitude')[0]
mi += 1e-9
mi, ma
In []: 
cam = get_im(ds, mi, ma, 'mag_field_pert_magnitude')
In []: 
tf = ytm.ColorTransferFunction((mi, ma), grey_opacity=False)
In []: 
fig = plt.figure(figsize=[8,8])
ax = plt.axes(xlim=(0, 512), ylim=(0, 512))
ax.axes.get_xaxis().set_visible(False)
ax.axes.get_yaxis().set_visible(False)
im = ax.imshow(np.ones([512,512,3]), origin='lower',)

def animate(i):
    ds = timeseries[i]
    ax.set_title('Magnetic Field Pertubation Magnitude\n $t = {:3.2f}$ s'.format(ds.current_time))
    im.set_data(get_im(ds, mi, ma, 'mag_field_pert_magnitude').snapshot('vm_rendering.png').swapaxes(0,1)[::-1])
    return im,

anim.FuncAnimation(fig, animate, frames=range(0,len(timeseries),50), interval=100)
